filme.storyline: Carly Norris is a book editor living in New York City who moves into the Sliver apartment building. In the apartment building, Carly meets two of her new neighbors, author Jack Lansford who writes thriller novels and Zeke Hawkins, the handsome owner of the apartment building. Carly finds that some of the women living in the apartment building have been murdered and the police suspect that there is a serial killer in the apartment building. Carly has a passionate and seductive love affair with Zeke, unaware Zeke has secretly wired the apartment building with hidden cameras and he has been watching the lives of each tenant living in the apartment building including Carly. Carly begins to suspect Zeke or Jack maybe the serial killer responsible for the murders in the apartment building and she maybe the killer's next victim.

If the sight of Sharon Stone and William Baldwin gyrating their way through a series of long and drawn-out sex scenes is appealing, then I'd recommend SLIVER, one in a wave of erotic thrillers that populated the mid-1990s in the wake of BASIC INSTINCT. For movie fans in general, though, SLIVER is a bit of a non-starter. The film's biggest flaw is an overly familiar script, which has an interesting premise involving voyeurism but does little with it (other than inviting the viewer to participate, a theme which has been done to death these days anyway). Sharon Stone moves into a high-tech apartment block where people are being murdered, and we're supposed to care about what happens next. There are flashes of interest and inspiration throughout, usually involving the supporting cast. Watching Tom Berenger chewing dialogue is always a delight, and ROME's Polly Walker shows up too, although sadly not for very long. The talents of CCH Pounder and Martin Landau also end up wasted in favour of dull, slightly wooden turns from Stone (who displays none of the charm and allure she essayed in BASIC INSTINCT) and a sweaty, unpleasant Baldwin. The thriller aspects are unevenly handled, and Aussie director Philip Noyce (who directed DEAD CALM, one of my favourite thrillers) drops the ball more than once, failing to elicit suspense from scenarios which should be tense and atmospheric. SLIVER isn't all bad; the most undemanding of movie fans might even enjoy it, but I'm afraid I've been here way too many times to see anything even remotely interesting.

William Baldwin is annoying as usual but he does his 'creepo' part quite OK. It was nice to see Tom Berenger, he was probably the best thing about the movie, his acting was kinda memorable so was his character. If you are looking for a tense, erotic thriller, you will be disappointed. It plays better as a drama, there is no suspense, no action, no real twists, nothing you would be excited about. 'Sliver' is barely watchable once. Do yourself a favor and pick the better choice.

I waited 18 years to see this movie because I had always heard how terrible it is. When it first came out, I seem to recall thinking it highly implausible that someone could have the kind of video and audio equipment you see in this movie. But the equipment and its use in the film is entirely plausible, even in 1993. I found no problems with the plot. It's an interesting thriller with something that's hard to find--a unique story that hasn't been told a thousand times already. The acting is good. The characters and their actions are completely believable. I was never left thinking that a real person might not have done the things that the people in the movie did. Having seen the movie, I really don't understand why so many people criticize it so harshly. In terms of telling a compelling, entertaining story, I would say it is far better than movies like Hereafter and on par with a movie like the Adjustment Bureau (just two recent movies I could think to compare it to). If you haven't seen it, give it a chance.

This may be due to the fact that Philip Noyce, who is responsible for unmemorable films like "The Saint" and "Patriot Games", is certainly no director comparable to Paul Verhoeven, one of the few directors who successfully mix Exploitation cinema with Blockbuster budgets, most successfully with "Basic Instinct" and films like "Robo Cop", "Total Recall", "Flesh+Blood" or "Showgirls". Stone plays Carly Norris, a beautiful and successful writer of biographies, who has become vulnerable and insecure ever since splitting from her boyfriend. She moves into the posh Manhattan apartment complex Sliver heights. The former tenant, a woman who had an amazing resemblance to Carly is supposed to have killed herself - only that in reality, it was someone else who threw her off her 13th floor balcony. And someone is watching the house's tenants via hidden cameras... In case you haven't seen the film, don't read on. ***WARNING! From the beginning, we can see that somebody is watching the tenants 24/7, and it is clear that a murderer is on the loose. Several characters are introduced, and it is quite clear who is responsible for what. When moving into the apartment complex, sexy Sharon meets the handsome and friendly Zeke (William Baldwin) and it's immediately clear that there's a sexual tension between the two. Carly falls for Zeke, and at the latest when Zeke confesses to Carly that he is the owner of the house, it is clear who has been watching her take a shower on a silver screen. Then there's a sleazy and self-centered writer played by Tom Berenger. The guy basically has 'MANIAC' written all over him, and... Surprise!... Now I Would not call "Sliver" a complete failure. The film has some interesting points and the assumption that the voyeur is in all of us is quite well-illustrated. Sharon stone is stunningly beautiful in this film, and she also delivers a great performance. Seeing sexy Sharon bare it is sufficient reason to watch the film, and yet, she did so far more explicitly in "Basic Instinct" a year earlier. The supporting cast includes the great Martin Landau, and sexy young Polly Walker, who is most famous for her recent role of the ueber-intriguer Attia of the Julii on HBO's brilliant mini-series "Rome". Tom Berenger is typecast as a sleazy scumbag, and William Baldwin is convincing as the rich playboy with the sleazy hobby. - And yet, it is not really convincing at all. The film is full of inconsistencies. At one point, Zeke threatens a guy on the phone for molesting his stepdaughter. Would a man who spends his time secretly watching the tenants of an apartment complex in intimate situations really care? And even if he did, would he take any risks to be discovered? I don't think so, and this is only one of many illogical things about the film. What I, as a Horror fan, found interesting was the fact that the murders are very much in the style of Italian 70s Gialli. Director Noyce obviously let Horror's most intriguing sub-genre, the wonderful Giallo, serve as an inspiration here. Overall, "Sliver" is mildly entertaining for its exploration of voyeurism, and for satisfying the viewer's voyeurism by providing female eye-candy in form of sexy leading lady Sharon Stone. As a mystery, however, it fails. If you do, watch it for Sharon's boobies.

I waited 18 years to see this movie because I had always heard how terrible it is. When it first came out, I seem to recall thinking it highly implausible that someone could have the kind of video and audio equipment you see in this movie. But the equipment and its use in the film is entirely plausible, even in 1993. I found no problems with the plot. It's an interesting thriller with something that's hard to find--a unique story that hasn't been told a thousand times already. The acting is good. The characters and their actions are completely believable. I was never left thinking that a real person might not have done the things that the people in the movie did. Having seen the movie, I really don't understand why so many people criticize it so harshly. If you haven't seen it, give it a chance.

Even so, "Sliver" of 1993 is a barely mediocre film that does not nearly reach the high standards of mystery and suspense it seems to think. Comparisons with "Basic Instinct" (1992) are obvious, as both films are early 90s erotic thrillers from the sleazy mind of Joe Esterhas, and both films star sexy Sharon Stone on the peak of her career. Yet, "Sliver" is far less interesting a film. Not because the script is weaker, but mainly because this is a lot tamer than the scandalous "Basic Instinct", and because there are several periods of mere boredom in-between. This may be due to the fact that Philip Noyce, who is responsible for unmemorable films like "The Saint" and "Patriot Games", is certainly no director comparable to Paul Verhoeven, one of the few directors who successfully mix Exploitation cinema with Blockbuster budgets, most successfully with "Basic Instinct" and films like "Robo Cop", "Total Recall", "Flesh+Blood" or "Showgirls". The character Stone plays here is the total opposite to the Femme Fatale she played in "Basic Insinct". Stone plays Carly Norris, a beautiful and successful writer of biographies, who has become vulnerable and insecure ever since splitting from her boyfriend. She moves into the posh Manhattan apartment complex Sliver heights. The former tenant, a woman who had an amazing resemblance to Carly is supposed to have killed herself - only that in reality, it was someone else who threw her off her 13th floor balcony. And someone is watching the house's tenants via hidden cameras... In case you haven't seen the film, don't read on. ***WARNING! BIG SPOILERS AHEAD!*** What I disliked most about "Sliver" is the fact that it tries to be unpredictable, but is predictable all the way. From the beginning, we can see that somebody is watching the tenants 24/7, and it is clear that a murderer is on the loose. Several characters are introduced, and it is quite clear who is responsible for what. When moving into the apartment complex, sexy Sharon meets the handsome and friendly Zeke (William Baldwin) and it's immediately clear that there's a sexual tension between the two. Carly falls for Zeke, and at the latest when Zeke confesses to Carly that he is the owner of the house, it is clear who has been watching her take a shower on a silver screen. Then there's a sleazy and self-centered writer played by Tom Berenger. The guy basically has 'MANIAC' written all over him, and... Surprise!... Now I Would not call "Sliver" a complete failure. The film has some interesting points and the assumption that the voyeur is in all of us is quite well-illustrated. Sharon stone is stunningly beautiful in this film, and she also delivers a great performance. Seeing sexy Sharon bare it is sufficient reason to watch the film, and yet, she did so far more explicitly in "Basic Instinct" a year earlier. The supporting cast includes the great Martin Landau, and sexy young Polly Walker, who is most famous for her recent role of the ueber-intriguer Attia of the Julii on HBO's brilliant mini-series "Rome". Tom Berenger is typecast as a sleazy scumbag, and William Baldwin is convincing as the rich playboy with the sleazy hobby. - And yet, it is not really convincing at all. The film is full of inconsistencies. At one point, Zeke threatens a guy on the phone for molesting his stepdaughter. Would a man who spends his time secretly watching the tenants of an apartment complex in intimate situations really care? And even if he did, would he take any risks to be discovered? If the sight of Sharon Stone and William Baldwin gyrating their way through a series of long and drawn-out sex scenes is appealing, then I'd recommend SLIVER, one in a wave of erotic thrillers that populated the mid-1990s in the wake of BASIC INSTINCT. For movie fans in general, though, SLIVER is a bit of a non-starter. The film's biggest flaw is an overly familiar script, which has an interesting premise involving voyeurism but does little with it (other than inviting the viewer to participate, a theme which has been done to death these days anyway). Sharon Stone moves into a high-tech apartment block where people are being murdered, and we're supposed to care about what happens next. There are flashes of interest and inspiration throughout, usually involving the supporting cast. Watching Tom Berenger chewing dialogue is always a delight, and ROME's Polly Walker shows up too, although sadly not for very long. The talents of CCH Pounder and Martin Landau also end up wasted in favour of dull, slightly wooden turns from Stone (who displays none of the charm and allure she essayed in BASIC INSTINCT) and a sweaty, unpleasant Baldwin. The thriller aspects are unevenly handled, and Aussie director Philip Noyce (who directed DEAD CALM, one of my favourite thrillers) drops the ball more than once, failing to elicit suspense from scenarios which should be tense and atmospheric. SLIVER isn't all bad; the most undemanding of movie fans might even enjoy it, but I'm afraid I've been here way too many times to see anything even remotely interesting.

'Sliver' is barely watchable once. Do yourself a favor and pick the better choice.

review.conteudo: Sliver starts out fine, but it ages like milk, and by the end, it kind of stinks Dumb would be the easiest way to label Sliver, but to be more specific, I would call it immature. This is the kind of material where high profile people have low profile brains, resulting in a motion picture which intends to be dramatic by relying almost entirely on characters doing and saying vulgar, improper things: icky flirting, gratuitous sex and biggest of all, invading the privacy of others. Voyeurism is the main topic here. Having its roots Hitchcock, Sliver tries to take the peeping tom effect to the highest high it seems. Director Phillip Noyce sells it to us well visually, but he is unable to use it effectively as a plot device or for suspense. The cast are unable to perform with solidity, the story is unable to achieve focus, and the end product is not recommendable, even for those who get off on erotic thrillers. Try looking somewhere else.

Granted, the idea of the voyeur that sleeps in all of could provide interesting film material. Providing a potent cast including a leading role for foxy Sharon Stone who doesn't scant with female charms should only make this material more worthwhile. Even so, "Sliver" of 1993 is a barely mediocre film that does not nearly reach the high standards of mystery and suspense it seems to think. Comparisons with "Basic Instinct" (1992) are obvious, as both films are early 90s erotic thrillers from the sleazy mind of Joe Esterhas, and both films star sexy Sharon Stone on the peak of her career. Yet, "Sliver" is far less interesting a film. Not because the script is weaker, but mainly because this is a lot tamer than the scandalous "Basic Instinct", and because there are several periods of mere boredom in-between. This may be due to the fact that Philip Noyce, who is responsible for unmemorable films like "The Saint" and "Patriot Games", is certainly no director comparable to Paul Verhoeven, one of the few directors who successfully mix Exploitation cinema with Blockbuster budgets, most successfully with "Basic Instinct" and films like "Robo Cop", "Total Recall", "Flesh+Blood" or "Showgirls". The character Stone plays here is the total opposite to the Femme Fatale she played in "Basic Insinct". Stone plays Carly Norris, a beautiful and successful writer of biographies, who has become vulnerable and insecure ever since splitting from her boyfriend. She moves into the posh Manhattan apartment complex Sliver heights. The former tenant, a woman who had an amazing resemblance to Carly is supposed to have killed herself - only that in reality, it was someone else who threw her off her 13th floor balcony. And someone is watching the house's tenants via hidden cameras... In case you haven't seen the film, don't read on. ***WARNING! BIG SPOILERS AHEAD!*** What I disliked most about "Sliver" is the fact that it tries to be unpredictable, but is predictable all the way. From the beginning, we can see that somebody is watching the tenants 24/7, and it is clear that a murderer is on the loose. Several characters are introduced, and it is quite clear who is responsible for what. When moving into the apartment complex, sexy Sharon meets the handsome and friendly Zeke (William Baldwin) and it's immediately clear that there's a sexual tension between the two. Carly falls for Zeke, and at the latest when Zeke confesses to Carly that he is the owner of the house, it is clear who has been watching her take a shower on a silver screen. Then there's a sleazy and self-centered writer played by Tom Berenger. The guy basically has 'MANIAC' written all over him, and... Surprise!... Now I Would not call "Sliver" a complete failure. The film has some interesting points and the assumption that the voyeur is in all of us is quite well-illustrated. Sharon stone is stunningly beautiful in this film, and she also delivers a great performance. Seeing sexy Sharon bare it is sufficient reason to watch the film, and yet, she did so far more explicitly in "Basic Instinct" a year earlier. The supporting cast includes the great Martin Landau, and sexy young Polly Walker, who is most famous for her recent role of the ueber-intriguer Attia of the Julii on HBO's brilliant mini-series "Rome". Tom Berenger is typecast as a sleazy scumbag, and William Baldwin is convincing as the rich playboy with the sleazy hobby. - And yet, it is not really convincing at all. The film is full of inconsistencies. At one point, Zeke threatens a guy on the phone for molesting his stepdaughter. Would a man who spends his time secretly watching the tenants of an apartment complex in intimate situations really care? And even if he did, would he take any risks to be discovered? I don't think so, and this is only one of many illogical things about the film. What I, as a Horror fan, found interesting was the fact that the murders are very much in the style of Italian 70s Gialli. Director Noyce obviously let Horror's most intriguing sub-genre, the wonderful Giallo, serve as an inspiration here. Overall, "Sliver" is mildly entertaining for its exploration of voyeurism, and for satisfying the viewer's voyeurism by providing female eye-candy in form of sexy leading lady Sharon Stone. As a mystery, however, it fails. If you do, watch it for Sharon's boobies.
